posts.post_content: The founder of an archetype. Obviously it's not the powerhouse it once was, but it's still perfectly playable and if anything, less annoying in the wake of things like [Grindstone](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Grindstone) and [Glimpse the Unthinkable](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glimpse the Unthinkable). It generally raises a smile when activated.
posts.html:
The founder of an archetype. Obviously it's not the powerhouse it once was, but it's still perfectly playable and if anything, less annoying in the wake of things like Grindstone and Glimpse the Unthinkable. It generally raises a smile when activated.

Posted By: stygimoloch (2/15/2009 4:01:41 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@sonorhC - It seems you need a lesson in mill, as you would state: "for noobs":  
  
Win by turn 3: [Grindstone](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Grindstone) + [Painter's Servant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Painter's Servant) = entire library gone to graveyard due to infinite-loop mill. Game over unless you have a Platinum Angel in play.  
  
Win by turn 5: [Drowner of Secrets](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Drowner of Secrets) + [Stonybrook Schoolmaster](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stonybrook Schoolmaster) + [Intruder Alarm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Intruder Alarm) = infi-loop mill, entire library is gone, plus an army of 1/1 merfolk equal to the size of the library that was milled.  
  
Mill is far more "relevant" than the four points you made. By no means am I saying mill is foolproof, but it can be a very relevant way to win.  
  
Furthermore, your "For comparison" section is a very poor comparison. A card put on the bottom of the library is not even close to "just as gone" as a card put into the graveyard. A card put on the bottom of the library can be readily available after a single shuffle. A mill deck including [Leyline o](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leyline o)... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Mill is far more "relevant" than the four points you made. By no means am I saying mill is foolproof, but it can be a very relevant way to win.

Posted By: Duskdale_Wurm (6/6/2010 6:53:46 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
One of the most misunderstood mechanics, for noobs. The thing is, by itself, mill doesn't really do anything. Yeah, those are two cards you'll never see, but you'll see everything below those two cards quicker.  
  
For comparison: Suppose this card instead said "put two cards from the top of target player's library onto the bottom of that player's library". Then, it'd be obvious that it does nothing by itself, but really, the bottom of a library is just as gone as the graveyard is.  
  
There are only a few situations where mill is relevant:  
1: If you actually manage to mill away someone's entire library. But it takes an awful lot of mill to accomplish that; this card by itself won't get you anywhere close.  
2: It fills up graveyards, to fuel reanimation and dredge and the like. If your opponent is playing one of those styles, you don't want to help him out.  
3: Your opponent sees which cards he's missing out on, and can plan accordingly. Well, you can, too, but since your opponent pr... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
One of the most misunderstood mechanics, for noobs. The thing is, by itself, mill doesn't really do anything. Yeah, those are two cards you'll never see, but you'll see everything below those two cards quicker.

For comparison: Suppose this card instead said "put two cards from the top of target player's library onto the bottom of that player's library". Then, it'd be obvious that it does nothing by itself, but really, the bottom of a library is just as gone as the graveyard is.

There are only a few situations where mill is relevant:
1: If you actually manage to mill away someone's entire library. But it takes an awful lot of mill to accomplish that; this card by itself won't get you anywhere close.
2: It fills up graveyards, to fuel reanimation and dredge and the like. If your opponent is playing one of those styles, you don't want to help him out.
3: Your opponent sees which cards he's missing out on, and can plan accordingly. Well, you can, too, but since your opponent pr... (see all)
